On 6/1/06, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
> I disagre=
e that there is a limited responsibility.  A developer
> should not release=
 code that they haven't tested.  They should not
> release a line of code t=
hat they have not tested.  Every line, every
> statement, every condition s=
hould be tested before the developer
> releases the code.  It seems to me t=
hat's a minimum professional
> standard.  Releasing code that you have not =
thoroughly tested is,
> simply, unprofessional.


That's a bit extreme, but=
 not contradictory with what I said earlier.

I can't really think of any p=
roject I worked on where I knew deep inside
that 100% of the code I or my c=
olleagues wrote was tested.  It's a fact of
life:  we never ship the produc=
t we want, and at some point, we need to draw
the line.

Developers need to=
 test their code, but I'm a bit more lenient on "how" they
do it.  Ideally,=
 I'd like them to use TDD, but if they can make a reasonable
case for not d=
oing TDD, I'll be fine with it as long as they provide
reasonable tests.

T=
here is also another aspect that is often overlooked in the kind of
discuss=
ion we're having right now:  QA departments.

Open source projects are idea=
l Petri dishes:  if the developers are the
bleeding edge kind, they will ty=
pically write code and supply 100% of the
tests.  Things are quite differen=
t in the industry and it's very common to
see engineering and QA share the =
load of testing.  When you start factoring
this in, the impact of TDD becom=
es harder to quantify.

At the very least, I expect developers to write "pa=
ssing" tests for their
code, but after this, it's quite common to see these=
 tests passed along to
QA which will expand on them and bring their own min=
dset and experience.

I have been fortunate to work with very talented QA e=
ngineers who were
absolutely brilliant at improving the tests initially sup=
plied by the
developers, and obviously, TDD is quite irrelevant for these Q=
A departments
since the code has already been written.

-- 
C=E9dric
